text: hey everybody Thomas Joseph here and
today we are tackling toffee now toffee
and caramels are problematic for the
home cook and maybe that's because you

to share with you some of those really
important details and it's actually
really easy to make I have a very deep

this is a very important piece of
cooking equipment that you will need if
you are going to make a lot of
confections or candies at home it is a
deep fat frying thermometer or a candy
thermometer and it has the temperatures
that go up the side and it actually
notes for you the specific stages at
which candy or sugars reach a certain
temperature and what that will yield in
the cooled syrup so we're gonna get

and this is two and two thirds cup of
regular granulated sugar that goes right
into my pot here I'm going to add 1/3 of
a cup of regular water and the water's
gonna help in dissolving the sugar and
helping it to melt and caramelize evenly
so it is an important ingredient that
you should add to this mix here in
addition to the sugar I'm also adding a
little bit of corn syrup now corn syrup
is going to help with two things it's
gonna help in terms of stabilizing the
toffee or the caramel mixture so that we
kind of avoid separation or
crystallization and it's also going to
help in softening the toffee so that
it's not too hard and too crunchy where
it might crack your tooth now to this
I'm going to add butter this is one
pound or four sticks of unsalted butter
and this is the main difference in
caramel versus toffee so Toffees have
some sort of dairy component that's
added in the beginning stages so before
it is boiled and cooked as opposed to a
caramel which just is a sugar mixture a
sugar syrup that is then boiled and
caramelized so I'm gonna add all this
butter in right from the start and I'm
going to turn the heat on to a low
temperature so start your toffee out at
a low temperature because what that does
is it helps all of the ingredients kind
of melt at the at a similar rate and
this will prevent separation so you
don't really have to worry that much
about crystallization here like you
would with a caramel but one thing that
people have problems with when it comes
to toffee is separation is the butter
separating from the caramel so doing
this first step at a lower temperature
will help in preventing that so just
stir it together with I have a silicone
or rubber spatula here you could use a
wooden spoon mix it together melt this
down on low before we begin the boiling
process where we want this mixture then
to reach a certain temperature and that
temperature is 300 degrees Fahrenheit
and 300 degrees Fahrenheit is considered
the hard crack stage and hard crack
means just that you guys in that when
the mixture is completely cooled it will
crack so it's been about a few minutes
here over medium heat and I've been
stirring every so often helping to

grittiness or any granules of sugar left
over so the sugar is dissolved the
butters melted now I'm going to crank
this up to a medium high heat here and
really we want this mixture now to cook
undisturbed it's gonna boil up and
that's kind of why we have a tall pot
here that we're using and really what
we're looking for is the temperature to
reach 300 degrees and that will take
anywhere between 10 to 12 minutes
depending on your heat source that might
even take a
little bit longer so make sure you
invest in one of these really great
thermometers and keep an eye on the

want to avoid here is stirring at this
point because we don't want to encourage
this mixture to separate so we're up to
300 degrees we're actually a tiny bit
over so now is the time to pour this out

here guys just to mix it together and
